expanded_description: This section introduces orbital motion—the movement of objects around larger bodies due to gravity. Students will learn how gravity provides the centripetal force that keeps planets orbiting the Sun, moons orbiting planets, and satellites circling Earth, and discover the relationship between orbital speed, radius, and period.

core_concept.principle: Orbital motion occurs when gravity provides exactly the centripetal force needed to keep an object moving in a circular path around a larger body.
core_concept.explanation: Newton imagined a cannonball fired from a mountaintop. The faster it's fired, the farther it travels before hitting Earth. At just the right speed, it falls around Earth rather than into it—continuously falling but never hitting, because Earth's curvature matches its curved path. This is orbit: continuous free fall with gravity as the centripetal force.

image.alt: Newton's cannonball thought experiment showing trajectories at different speeds, with one going into orbit
image.caption: Newton's cannonball: at the right speed, the object orbits instead of hitting the ground

sections.introduction: Look up at the night sky and you'll see the Moon. Look around and you're standing on Earth, which is orbiting the Sun. Orbital motion is everywhere in the universe—objects moving in curved paths around larger bodies, with gravity pulling them inward as centripetal force.

key_concept.definition: Orbital motion is the movement of an object (like a planet, moon, or satellite) around a larger body due to the gravitational force providing the centripetal force needed for circular (or elliptical) motion.
key_concept.context: Orbits can be circular (simpler to understand) or elliptical (more common in nature). For grade 9-10, we focus on circular orbits to apply our circular motion understanding.

principles.statement: In orbital motion, the gravitational force between two objects provides exactly the centripetal force needed to keep the smaller object in circular motion around the larger one.
principles.application: The same force that makes apples fall also keeps the Moon in orbit—gravity acts at a distance, constantly pulling the orbiting object toward the center.
principles.example: Earth's gravity pulls on the Moon with a force of about $2 \times 10^{20}$ N. This force is exactly what the Moon needs as centripetal force to stay in its orbit.
principles.analogy: Orbit is like a never-ending game of catch between gravity and inertia—gravity pulls inward, inertia wants to go straight, and the balance creates a circular path.

principles.statement: Objects in orbit are actually in continuous free fall toward the body they're orbiting—but they keep missing because of their forward speed.
principles.application: Astronauts on the International Space Station appear weightless because they're in free fall along with their spacecraft. They're not
—they're falling, but so is everything around them!
principles.example: The ISS falls toward Earth constantly, but its forward speed (about 7.66 km/s) means Earth curves away beneath it at the same rate it falls.

image.alt: Diagram showing an orbiting object with gravity pulling inward and velocity tangent to the circle
image.caption: In orbit, gravity provides centripetal force while inertia wants to go straight—balance creates the circle

sections.introduction: Isaac Newton imagined a brilliant thought experiment that explains orbital motion perfectly. Understanding this helps visualize how orbits work.

key_concept.definition: Newton imagined a cannon on a very tall mountain firing cannonballs horizontally at different speeds. At low speeds, they hit the ground nearby. At higher speeds, they travel farther. At one special speed, they fall completely around Earth and return to their starting point—they're in orbit.
key_concept.context: This thought experiment shows that orbit is really just a special case of projectile motion—where the curvature of Earth matches the curved path of the projectile.

classifications.behavior: At low speeds, gravity pulls the cannonball down, and it hits the ground at some distance from the mountain.

examples.explanation: A normal cannonball follows a parabolic arc and lands relatively close.

classifications.value: Cannonball travels farther, but still hits
classifications.behavior: As speed increases, the cannonball travels farther before hitting—but it still hits because Earth's surface is curved, and the ball's path curves more steeply.

examples.explanation: Very fast projectiles can travel halfway around Earth before hitting.

classifications.value: Cannonball continuously falls but never hits
classifications.behavior: At just the right speed (about 7.9 km/s for low Earth orbit), the cannonball's curved path matches Earth's curve. It falls exactly as fast as Earth curves away beneath it.

examples.explanation: All satellites are essentially Newton's cannonballs—fired fast enough to keep missing Earth.
The ISS is in continuous free fall around Earth at orbital speed.

characteristics: Path is less curved than Earth
classifications.behavior: At speeds above about 11.2 km/s (escape velocity), the cannonball's path is too straight—gravity can't pull it into a closed loop. It escapes Earth's gravity and heads into space.

examples.explanation: Voyager, New Horizons, and other deep space probes were launched at escape velocity to leave Earth forever.

image.alt: Newton's cannonball diagram showing trajectories at different speeds: A, B, C hitting at different distances, D in orbit, E escaping
image.caption: Different speeds produce different trajectories—only the right speed creates an orbit

sections.introduction: We can use our circular motion understanding to find the speed needed for a circular orbit. Since gravity provides centripetal force, we can set the gravitational force equal to the centripetal force formula.

key_concept.definition: For a circular orbit, the gravitational force ($F_g = G\frac{Mm}{r^2}$) equals the required centripetal force ($F_c = \frac{mv^2}{r}$). Solving for v gives $v = \sqrt{\frac{GM}{r}}$.
key_concept.context: This formula tells us that orbital speed depends only on the mass of the central body (M) and the orbital radius (r)—not on the mass of the orbiting object (which cancels out)!

principles.application: The mass of the orbiting object (m) cancels out—amazingly, all objects at the same distance from a body orbit at the same speed regardless of their mass!
principles.example: A tiny satellite and a massive space station at the same altitude need the same orbital speed—about 7.8 km/s for low Earth orbit.
principles.analogy: Think of it like this: heavier objects need more force to orbit, but gravity pulls harder on heavier objects. It balances perfectly—like the mass cancellation we saw with friction on curves!

principles.application: This is the speed needed for a circular orbit at radius r around a body of mass M.
principles.example: For Earth, $M = 5.97 \times 10^{24}$ kg, $G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11}$. For a satellite at $r = 7,000$ km ($7 \times 10^6$ m), $v = \sqrt{(6.67 \times 10^{-11} \times 5.97 \times 10^{24}) / (7 \times 10^6)}$

principles.statement: From $v = \sqrt{GM/r}$, we see: farther orbits = slower speeds.
principles.application: Objects in higher orbits (larger r) move more slowly than those in low orbits. This seems counterintuitive—but it's true!
principles.example: The ISS orbits at about 400 km altitude (r ≈ 6,770 km) at 7.66 km/s. The Moon orbits at 384,000 km at only about 1 km/s—much slower!

worked_examples.title: Calculating Orbital Speed
worked_examples.problem: Calculate the orbital speed for a satellite at 400 km above Earth's surface. Earth's radius is 6,370 km, and Earth's mass is $5.97 \times 10^{24}$ kg. $G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11}$.

step_by_step.explanation: r = Earth's radius + altitude = 6,370 km + 400 km = 6,770 km = $6.77 \times 10^6$ m

worked_examples.final_answer: The orbital speed is approximately 7.67 km/s.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Orbital speed depends on mass of central body and radius.

worked_examples.title: Comparing Orbital Speeds
worked_examples.problem: Compare the orbital speed of a satellite at 400 km altitude to one at 36,000 km altitude (geostationary orbit). Earth's mass is $5.97 \times 10^{24}$ kg, radius 6,370 km.
worked_examples.final_answer: The geostationary satellite moves at only 40% of the speed of the low-Earth orbit satellite—about 3.1 km/s compared to 7.7 km/s.

sections.introduction: We can also find how long an orbit takes—the orbital period. This is important for satellites that need to stay over the same spot or pass over regularly.

key_concept.definition: The orbital period T is the time to complete one full orbit. Using $v = \frac{2\pi r}{T}$ and $v = \sqrt{\frac{GM}{r}}$, we get $T = 2\pi \sqrt{\frac{r^3}{GM}}$.
key_concept.context: This is Kepler's Third Law of planetary motion! It shows that the square of the period is proportional to the cube of the orbital radius.

principles.application: This formula tells us that farther orbits take much longer—period increases faster than radius because of the $r^3$ term.
principles.example: The ISS (r ≈ 6,770 km) takes about 90 minutes. The Moon (r ≈ 384,000 km) takes about 27.3 days—much longer because radius is 57 times larger!

principles.statement: A special orbit exists where the period equals Earth's rotation period (24 hours).
principles.application: Satellites in this geostationary orbit appear fixed in the sky—perfect for communications and weather satellites.
principles.example: To have T = 24 hours, we can solve for r: $r = \sqrt[3]{\frac{GMT^2}{4\pi^2}}$. This gives r ≈ 42,000 km from Earth's center (about 36,000 km altitude).

worked_examples.title: Finding Orbital Period
worked_examples.problem: Calculate the period of the ISS orbiting at r = 6,770 km from Earth's center. $M = 5.97 \times 10^{24}$ kg, $G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11}$.
worked_examples.final_answer: The ISS orbital period is approximately 92.4 minutes.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Period depends on orbital radius and central mass.

sections.introduction: Different orbits serve different purposes. Understanding orbital motion helps explain why satellites are placed at specific altitudes.

classifications.behavior: Satellites in LEO move quickly and see different parts of Earth each orbit. Good for imaging, science, and the ISS.

examples.explanation: Orbits at ~400 km, period ~90 minutes. Astronauts see 16 sunrises/sunsets per day!
Take high-resolution images as they pass over different locations.
Orbits at ~540 km to get clear views above atmosphere.

classifications.behavior: Satellites at this altitude have longer periods and cover larger areas.

examples.explanation: Orbit at about 20,000 km altitude with period ~12 hours. This allows good coverage with fewer satellites.

classifications.behavior: Satellites here stay over the same spot on Earth continuously. Perfect for communications and weather monitoring.

examples.explanation: Constantly watch the same hemisphere, providing continuous weather images.
TV and phone satellites in GEO allow dishes to point at fixed positions.

image.alt: Diagram showing LEO, MEO, and GEO orbits around Earth with altitude labels
image.caption: Different orbits serve different purposes—LEO is fast and close, GEO is slow and fixed

sections.introduction: This is the most common question about orbits. The answer lies in understanding that satellites ARE falling—they're just falling around Earth instead of into it.

key_concept.definition: Satellites don't fall to Earth because their forward speed is so high that as they fall, Earth curves away beneath them at the same rate.
key_concept.context: Imagine throwing a ball horizontally. It falls to the ground because Earth is flat (locally). But Earth is round—if you throw it fast enough, it falls all the way around and comes back to you.

principles.statement: A satellite has two motions simultaneously: it's moving forward at high speed, and it's falling toward Earth due to gravity.
principles.application: These combine to create a curved path. If the forward speed is just right, the curve matches Earth's curve.
principles.example: The ISS moves forward at 7.66 km/s and falls toward Earth at the same rate Earth curves away. Result: it stays at constant altitude.

principles.statement: If a satellite stopped moving forward, it would fall straight down like any dropped object.
principles.application: This is why satellites need periodic boosts—atmospheric drag (even tiny) slows them, reducing forward speed. Eventually they fall to Earth if not boosted.
principles.example: The ISS gets regular boosts from visiting spacecraft to maintain its orbit against tiny atmospheric drag.

worked_examples.title: Explaining Weightlessness
worked_examples.problem: Astronauts on the ISS appear weightless. Some people think this means there's no gravity. Explain what's really happening.

step_by_step.explanation: At ISS altitude (400 km), gravity is still about 90% as strong as on Earth's surface.
The ISS and astronauts are in continuous free fall toward Earth. They're falling together.
Weightlessness happens because there's no support force—everything falls at the same rate. It's like being in a falling elevator, but permanently.

worked_examples.final_answer: Astronauts aren't weightless because gravity is absent—gravity is still strong! They're weightless because they're in continuous free fall, with no floor pushing up against them. Everything falls together, creating the sensation of weightlessness.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Orbit is free fall, and free fall creates apparent weightlessness.

sections.introduction: The same principles apply to planets orbiting the Sun and moons orbiting planets. Gravity governs motion on the largest scales.

categories.description: Earth orbits the Sun at about 150 million km distance.

examples.explanation: Earth moves at about 30 km/s (108,000 km/h!) in its orbit. That's fast enough to go from New York to Los Angeles in about 2 minutes.
One year = 365 days. Using $T = 2\pi \sqrt{r^3/GM}$ with M = Sun's mass gives exactly this.
Seasons come from Earth's tilt, not distance—in fact, Earth is slightly closer to Sun in Northern Hemisphere winter!

categories.description: The Moon orbits Earth at about 384,000 km.

examples.explanation: The Moon moves at only about 1 km/s—much slower than low Earth satellites because it's much farther.
The Moon's 27.3-day orbital period gives us our months and lunar phases.
The Moon's gravity causes ocean tides—another example of gravity at work across space.

categories.description: All planets follow Kepler's laws—farther planets orbit more slowly and take longer years.

examples.explanation: Closest to Sun, orbits in just 88 Earth days at about 48 km/s.
5 times farther than Earth, takes 12 Earth years for one orbit at about 13 km/s.
30 times farther than Earth, takes 165 Earth years for one orbit at about 5 km/s.

image.alt: Diagram of solar system showing planetary orbits with relative sizes and speeds indicated
image.caption: Inner planets orbit faster; outer planets orbit slower—all obey $v = \sqrt{GM/r}$

sections.introduction: Apply your understanding of orbital motion.

worked_examples.title: Problem 1: Orbital Speed
worked_examples.problem: A satellite orbits Mars at 500 km altitude. Mars' radius is 3,390 km, mass is $6.39 \times 10^{23}$ kg. $G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11}$. Find orbital speed.
worked_examples.final_answer: The orbital speed is approximately 3.32 km/s.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Orbital speed depends on central body mass and radius.

worked_examples.title: Problem 2: Orbital Period
worked_examples.problem: What is the orbital period for the Mars satellite in problem 1?
worked_examples.final_answer: The orbital period is approximately 123 minutes (about 2 hours).

worked_examples.title: Problem 3: Comparing Orbits
worked_examples.problem: Satellite A orbits Earth at 400 km altitude. Satellite B orbits at 800 km altitude. Which has higher speed? Which has longer period?

step_by_step.explanation: $v \propto 1/\sqrt{r}$, so larger r means smaller v
Satellite B has larger r (800 vs 400 km), so it has LOWER speed
$T \propto \sqrt{r^3}$, so larger r means much larger T
Satellite B has larger r, so it has LONGER period

worked_examples.final_answer: Satellite A (lower altitude) has higher speed. Satellite B (higher altitude) has longer period.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Higher orbit = slower speed, longer period.

worked_examples.title: Problem 4: Geostationary Orbit
worked_examples.problem: A geostationary satellite must have period = 24 hours. Earth's mass is $5.97 \times 10^{24}$ kg. Find its orbital radius.
worked_examples.final_answer: Geostationary orbit radius is about 42,200 km from Earth's center, altitude about 35,800 km.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Period determines orbital radius for given central body.

sections.introduction: Here are frequent misunderstandings about orbital motion.

principles.statement: Many think astronauts float because there's no gravity in space.
principles.application: Gravity is still strong in orbit—about 90% of surface gravity at ISS altitude. Weightlessness comes from free fall, not absence of gravity.
principles.example: If gravity stopped, the ISS would fly off in a straight line, not continue orbiting.

principles.principle: Misconception: Satellites are above the atmosphere, so no forces act
principles.statement: Some think satellites have no forces acting on them.
principles.application: Gravity is constantly acting on satellites—that's what keeps them in orbit! Also, tiny atmospheric drag exists even at ISS altitude.
principles.example: Satellites in LEO slowly lose altitude due to atmospheric drag and need boosts.

principles.principle: Misconception: Farther satellites move faster to cover larger distance
principles.statement: Intuitively, some think farther orbits need higher speed to get around in reasonable time.
principles.application: Actually, $v = \sqrt{GM/r}$ shows farther orbits are SLOWER. The Moon orbits at ~1 km/s, much slower than LEO satellites.
principles.example: This is why outer planets have longer years—they move slower AND have farther to go.

principles.principle: Misconception: Rockets need to reach orbit by going straight up
principles.statement: Many think rockets go straight up to reach space.
principles.application: Going to orbit requires going FAST sideways, not just up. Rockets go up first to get above thick atmosphere, then accelerate sideways to orbital speed.
principles.example: The Space Shuttle launched almost vertically but ended up going 17,500 mph sideways—that's the orbital speed!

sections.introduction: You can understand orbital motion through simple analogies and thought experiments.

process_flow.description: Imagine a ball on a string, swung in a circle. The string is like gravity—it pulls inward.
process_flow.mechanism: If you let go (remove gravity), the ball flies off tangent. If you pull harder (stronger gravity), it moves in tighter circle.
process_flow.result: This models how gravity keeps planets in orbit—the 'string' is invisible gravity.

process_flow.description: Draw a large circle representing Earth. Draw straight lines tangent to it at various points.
process_flow.mechanism: Notice how the straight lines quickly move away from the circle. Orbital speed is when the curved path matches Earth's curve.
process_flow.result: Visualizes why forward speed matters—too slow and path curves inside Earth (hit), too fast and path curves outside (escape).

process_flow.description: Water circling a drain moves faster near the center, slower farther out.
process_flow.mechanism: This mimics orbital motion—objects closer to the central body orbit faster.
process_flow.result: Analogous to inner planets moving faster than outer planets.

summary: Orbital motion occurs when gravity provides exactly the centripetal force needed to keep an object moving in a circular path around a larger body. Newton's cannonball thought experiment shows that orbit is really continuous free fall—objects fall toward Earth, but their forward speed makes them 'miss' as Earth curves away. The orbital speed formula $v = \sqrt{\frac{GM}{r}}$ reveals that speed depends only on the mass of the central body and orbital radius—not on the mass of the orbiting object. Higher orbits are slower orbits. The orbital period formula $T = 2\pi \sqrt{\frac{r^3}{GM}}$ shows that period increases dramatically with radius. Different orbits serve different purposes: Low Earth Orbit (LEO) for the ISS and imaging satellites, Medium Earth Orbit (MEO) for GPS, and Geostationary Orbit (GEO) for communications and weather satellites. Astronauts experience weightlessness not because gravity is absent, but because they're in continuous free fall. Understanding orbital motion connects our circular motion physics to the cosmos, explaining why planets move as they do and how we put satellites into precise orbits. This foundation prepares us for examining the apparent force called centrifugal force in the next section.
